reviewText:
Games mechanics are quite interesting. Takes a bit of time to get the hang of it, definitely one of those 'easy to learn, hard to master' experiences. Main gripe is the music track, there is only one, repeating track which while quite nice, will destroy your soul after half an hour.

Game modes, difficulty settings, customisable number of AI per match, even an autoplay mode where you 'do not' play, but watch AI duke it out. Needs multiplayer, but apparently it is coming.

Game seems to be worth the price all in all. Defininitely recommend assuming you like the genre.

reviewText:
This is excellent! I got to try a demo of it at PAX South a month ago, and I thought it was a cool concept, but I wasn't sure how well it would actually work as a strategy game. I can now confirm that it works rather well indeed!

It's very different from any RTS I've played before. Instead of issuing orders to individual units, you're trying to shape an every-shifting pattern into something resembling an army. And, seemingly inevitably, the whole thing grows out of your control: you can't be everywhere at once, and if you spend a minute focussing on one side of the map you're likely to find that your monsters on the other side have mindlessly spread out and populated whole areas.

The standard WAR!" deathmatch mode is pretty easy once you've learned some basic tactics: just flood the map with your units and you'll probably win. The other modes introduce some interesting twists; I've tried Capture the Flag a few times now
date: and every time I think I've got it figured out the AI does something unexpected and ruins me. The AI seems quite clever; it's pulled a few sneaky manoeuvres on me.\n\nI can't wait for multiplayer! Will this be the first RTS I'm actually good at? (Probably not.)"
helpfulPercent: 17 of 24 people (71%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Okay, holy crap. Indie RTS, how good could it be? Well, I couldn't stop playing! I set up to stream it and two and half hours had gone by before I realized! The music is great, the little monsters are adorable, and setting up feedback loops to launch your dudes at their dudes is really hypnotic and fun.  It's got way more depth than I realized, and it's got great macro and good micro strategy.

The different game modes feel really different - there's your standard wipe 'em out mode, there's one where you have to protect a big castle, another is king of the hill, and my favorite - Migration - where you have to get to the top of the map before the freaking undead take over. It's like game of thrones up in this, because those white walkers are eventually going to break down the wall!

There have got to be all sorts of little tricks, because you can set up feedback loops without even building Taverns. Taverns are the most basic structure, they force your dudes to go in a circle around it, so that they group up and reproduce. Then you can kind of build little off-ramps to let some pressure out of the loop - if you get too many dudes in one spot, they die! So you put an outlet on your loops and they keep sending dudes out forever, to crush your opponents.

Great. $9 is a steal, Nonadecimal is an idiot for only asking that much.

reviewText:
I really like this game. I was on the steam store and just happened to buy it the day (or maybe day after) it released and I was extremely pleased. The cellular automata idea is really a cool one.

That said, there are a couple things that need mentioning if you're thinking about buying it.
1. Knowledge of Conway's Game of Life would benefit you greatly. I've noticed a couple people saying they're confused by the mechanics, but it's just a modified version of Conway's Game of Life, turned into an actual game.
2. There are ways to annihilate the computer player easily. If you destroy all your buildings, your cells will propogate into the world quite well. That said, I don't think that's a problem. The idea of the game is to use strategy to defeat the opponent, and that's really fun to do. Letting the game play itself doesn't even benefit you. The value of a victory in this game is that you were able to outplay the opponent, so if you didn't play at all, you gain nothing from a win.

Neither of those are bad things, Just maybe something to keep in mind if you're thinking about buying it.

Overall I like the game, personally I think it's fine as it is, but I'm excited to see where it goes.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
The cellular automata core makes Automata Empire a really fun and interesting RTS.  I'm having fun setting up feedback loops to fuel the catapults in order to send those furballs screaming towards the enemy taverns.  WAAAR!

Each match is short and lasts about 15 minutes. The 5 games modes are unique/fun and offer a good amount of game variety. Migration is fun and has good tension when the zombie horde breaks through the wall starts flooding in!  It's mesmerizing watching 4 AI controlled players battle it out to see which will be the last remaining before getting overrun by the zombie horde.

Automata Empire is a pretty and fun RTS, and is totally worth the price!

reviewText:
very fun game, although takes a while to fully understand the whole feedback loop process thats needed to multiply rabidly and win games. Overall would definitely recommend to anyone that enjoys strategy games and having to think a bit, although there are a few of things that would make the game even better:

1.
training mode: So that new players can quickly grasp the main concept of the game alot better (abusing feedback loops/disrupting enemy feedback loops effectively)
2.
map editer type thing: would absolutely love creating unique maps with quircky game play from map design. Such as there being death pits everywhere, or lots of mountain ridges and setting up interesting zombie maps. With maybe the option to set preditermined spawn points + more AI players on these maps
3.
in game time controls: personally I think the the current speed of the game is fine and all, however having the option to slow down to 1/2 the speed or even pause at times to plan out your next moves would greatly be appreciated, as well having the option to go to 2x when you own 60% of the map and youre pretty much guaranteed to win.

reviewText:
Really great game inspired by The Game of Life; highly reccomended.

I bought it after looking at the screenshots and knowing it was an RTS, I wasn't really expecting too much from it, but so far I've been plesantly suprised.

The game revolves around building feedback loops (combinations of taverns, roads and walls designed to replicate monsters) and destroying / disrupting enemy feedback loops.  The mechanic allows for REALLY interesting designs, and I look forward to seeing what people do when multiplayer is added.

Ease of play: 9/10

Potential for competitive play: 9/10

Graphics: 8/10

Sound design: 7/10

Price: $9.99 CAD

Overall: 8.5

reviewText: Cellular Automata is a fun strategy game about, well, automatons which you will attempt (and miserably fail at first) to control.\n\nUnlike in other strategy games you cannot directly control your units, instead you can influence them through buildings such as roads or catapults, meaning winning is as much about engineering" as about fighting. The ressource system in this game is that each building costs units
date:
killing said units if they are nearby or otherwise failing to be built which adds more difficulties to building a massive wall for instance.
You can (and will) indeed kill yourself without all the help from anyone.

The principle of the game makes for really fun and interesting gameplay which is quite unique.

There are 5 game modes
voteText: king of the hill
helpfulPercent:
fort (defend a fort and protect it from enemies) and my personal favourite migration (you have a huge horde comming at you from the bottom and all players have to scramble to flee them while killing each other)

At the moment it does just have singleplayer which despite various gamemodes may for certain people not be worth it.
However if you are a strategy fan you should at the very least follow this game and wait for the multiplayer

reviewText:
Not recommended now for single player. Wait for multiplayer support maybe. This game seems to be more on the casual side. The enemy AI is not that bright so the game is very easy with little effort to strategizing a winning victory. I found myself just building random catapults (exactly 2 so it's not too many so they continue to multiply) to take the guys out of the initial town and then made them stay put to multiply near the landed spot by building taverns. Then built 2 catapults again to move them elsewhere and a tavern to have them multiply there. Then just rinse and repeat. Not too much strategy to it. Just multiply your guys like crazy as fast as possible which isn't too hard to do. As of now without multiplayer, the enemy AI is way too easy even on the hardest mode. I managed to beat the game on easy, medium and hard all in a row, my first 3 games. If played with other players then might be more of a challenge. I'll change my review if I see it's fun to play with others. I'm not entirely sure if playing with others is fun though since there's really not much strategy to it, but then again, I was never forced to use any strategy fighting against a really dumb enemy AI.

Content is very very lacking for a $9 price tag. You can get litterally 100x more content from games that are about $15 ilke Fortress Craft or a more similar game like Plague Evolved, Inc. which has a great multiplayer dynamic with much more interesting gameplay and truly a game difficult to master the strategy to. Or if you want another strategy game that's as simple as this, there's a ton of Casuals out there at $2 or less.

I'd say for the amount of content this game has, I would categorize it as Casual and I wouldn't pick it up for more than $1.99 as it stands now.

reviewText:
It looks like a lot of fun. The music and sounds were enjoyable and the gameplay SEEMS like it could be a lot of fun.

But then I spent 15 minues reading the 'help' and staring at the screen not knowing what to do, what was happening, or why things were happening. Started multiple games only to have of my things die off for ... some unexplained reason?

If there was some sort of explanation for what to do. Any sort of new players guide. A form of introduction. Literally anything, this game might have been enjoyable. But there's not. It's a game that would be great for people who like to be forced to work out everything themselves, and if that's your thing then I DO recommend this game, but it's not a game for people who want to just enjoy themselves because you won't be ABLE to play until after you've already gotten frustrated.
